etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in The Gentleman's Magazine. From sidero- + -graphy

definitions: A method of engraving formerly used especially for bank notes, in which multiple engraved printing plates could be made all bearing the same image.

notes.text: The design to be printed is first engraved on a soft steel block. This is hardened and then used to produce copies of the image in relief on a soft steel roller, by rocking the roller back and forth over the block. The roller is then hardened, and used to produce duplicate recessed images on further printing plates.
